review_title: Opportunistically Passive Aggressive (note: this is about the Commodities division)
pros:
- Opportunistic environment where one can attain and reach for clients and trade ideas beyond a set structure (theoretically).
- Sharp traders, industry leading risk taking ability
- Entrepreneurial culture: if you have an idea, you get a shot at it
- Not particularly bureaucratic environment
cons:
- Passive aggressive culture: management style is suitable for turning over employees, not building them. Average time around 2 years max. 
- Convoluted management hierarchy with up to 4 people to report to at VP level. Contributes to rampant confusion.
- Bad IT systems, overall the banks has an issue with investments in infrastructure.
- Little actual team work - not enough trust for that.

pros:
The brand name is a big pulse. People recognize the prestige and reputation of Morgan Stanley, and that helps a lot in the investment banking industry. 

The structure is pretty fixed as well, so that means good and clear opportunities to progress through the ranks, at least until VP level.
cons:
Work-life balance is non-existent. It is virtually impossible to arrange for a meal with absolute certainty that it won't get called off. Culture can be pretty passive and it is obvious that top management does not care about the lower ranks.

Expect 100-120 hour weeks, every week.

pros:
MS is probably the more envied employer (compared with other banks) in terms of culture. People/teams are less defensive & inhibited in working with each other, which really paves the way for working towards a given objective. Also of note, the staff spends more effort in fixing/preventing problems as opposed fault-finding and passing the blame.

Also helps that tech is good. And of course, the widely recognised/respected brand name.
cons:
Management: A slightly more hands-on upper management and better-trained middle management - less BS and/or being more straightforward would be good too.

Tech: not every tool/system actually solves a problem, but in fact causes more.

pros: It will look good on your resume to say you worked for Morgan Stanley.
cons: No relocation benefit or support and if you are not fully intergrated you might not get paid in the first months- they will not be bothered or accommodate you in any way. Impulsive managers can make your lives terrible; line managers can paint a narrative that will not be objectively reviewed that will negatively impact you- there are numerous Impulsive managers. Worst place to go if you're a person of African descent. What is said on paper is not what you will get- only count on your salary which you will need to stretch to live comfortably in a city like Budapest. Very few growth opportunities; it is possible that there isn't a single black manager or director and very few Indian, mixed or asian managers. Departments can be very Unproductive with mornings being dedicated to doing no work and people taking 2 to 3 hour lunches everyday- this ends up distorting the work-life balance because you will be expected to stay late everyday having wasted valuable time that could have been used productively during the day. Some managers can be very ignorant on the very work you do thus resulting in over reliance on knowledgeable subordinates. Little regard for employees. More than 500 people in risk in Budapest but African people are less than 10.

pros: There is not a single pro which i can mention. Sorry. Highly not recommended to anybody.
cons: 1. within 3 months of employment, you get fired for no reason. 2. employees are treated as robots, there is no work life balance. 3. employees are not treated as humans, they are not allowed to talk to each other, everything needs to be posted in office group chat, which is ridiculous. 4. new developers are treated as slaves by old/ exp developers. they want new ones to learn all their lengthy processes in few days once after joining, when they themselves learnt those processes only after spending 5-10 years in same organisation. 5. there is no welcoming culture, its always about work and nobody is helpful, even if u ask for little help, it will get displayed in your appraisal. 6. very tiring, no respect for new comers, only slave /toxic culture. One can go into depression, the way they treate their employees.

pros: Decent pay to employees, rewards and recognition to those who slog themselves throughout the year.
cons: Few but very important ones. 1. Forcing employees to work from office. 2. Long working hours (~12 hrs or more) 3. Too many dependencies which no one has clue and people try their best to avoid taking initiatives. 4. Consultants are slogging whereas majority of FTEs move like a turtle and they think like a BOSS. 5. Clear discrimination in recognizing efforts of consultants. 6. It is a boring place to work. 7. Work only for money, nothing more. 8. Old employees are too stubborn to adapt to new practices, they will try their best to give irrelevant logics just because they don't want to change. 9. You are expected to do everything in one role. 10. Process here is a myth. 11. They don't have dedicated QA teams; trust me if a dedicated QA team is involved in evaluating their products then they can rip off the system by finding loads of bugs. All the points are based on my experience and observations in approx 4 years. Worked with multiple teams and the situation is not great.

review_title: Be careful which team you join
job_title: VP- Risk in New York, NY
pros: - People you work with
cons: MS has lost its own essence. The company is massively hiring folks from other big banks where the culture is toxic, unfortunately. A lot of leaders are unqualified to do their job and due to the fact that there is a lack of guidance in respect to what needs to be done, you see people leaving groups or the firm after 6 months of employment. The culture is an hit too toxic and people are workaholic. At MS, you win if you know how to network and connect with the right people, Independently if you get any work done or not. It’s all About who you know..

review_title: Tech staff is treated as a commodity and a business cost
job_title: Software Developer in New York, NY
pros: Salary. It is not bad but definitely not great. Big financial name on your CV. For some reasons other companies will like it.
cons: Toxic workplace for junior employees. Most juniors are ignored and left alone and given crappy projects. No training, no mentora. Engineers are treated badly and not well-respected in general. Every other department of the company has a nice office but the tech staff is located into the older building that offers horrible coffee. At first I thought there was hope but finally no ... As I was hired during covid lockdowns I stayed there for a longer time hoping things would improve. This is obvious nothing will change even you stay at the company for years. This is a job for those who want to work on unchallenging tech projects, have an ok salary and be sure to keep your job forever even if you do nothing half of the day (this is VERY easy to do at that company)

pros: One of the few companies where I have seen people really sticking around and developing the systems to their full potential, rather than quick fixes. People are really professional, helping in to grow and learn the systems in the bank. Relatively less politics, and more work focused as compared to other banks that I have worked with.
cons: Bespoke platforms and systems, heavy investment into C++ based technologies is more of Pro than a Con, however for a modern world getting used to understand the systems takes a bit of a time. Although the people are really helpful and focused on improving the systems and not just getting the things done somehow.

review_title: Layoffs every two years - dishonest managers

cons: Layoffs every two years, dishonest managers.

review_title: Only join if you are joining a team you know
job_title: Service Associate in Walnut Creek, CA
pros: Some friendly faces with good advice and perspective on the industry. These are the teams to look out for and hopefully join.
cons: A lot of people will either not want to do parts of their job or cannot do them. As a Service Associate you will become accustomed of keeping records of all that you do, for many people will make mistakes and will look for someone else to blame. Don't let that be you.

job_title: Wealth Management Associate in Allentown, PA
pros: I think benefits are relatively generous. 5% 401k match, 10k tuition reimbursement, GymPass 50% subsidy. Job security is definitely big. You don't really feel worried when the market is down. And if you're looking to get experience in WM, it's a great place to be because you'll be surrounded by dozens of advisors. So you can learn what you DO and DON'T want to do with a future advisory biz. It's definitely a corporate setting, so you have a lot more protection from Lead FAs who can tend to be cutthroat in a small family practice.
cons: I haven't been at many other firms, so it's tough to measure this relatively, but I always feel like MS is rather restrictive in regards to what we can and can't do/say. I like freedom. The finance industry has a lot of red tape in general, but it feels excessive at MS. Constantly watching us on social media and every word we say.

review_title: As good as it can get for a software developer at a bank
job_title: Vice President Software Engineer in Budapest
pros: As a software developer, you can work with huge, complex, business-critical systems. Even though the technology isn't always today's latest, you can learn a lot about how to build, manage, and deploy such systems, learn a lot about design decisions, etc. At my team, we didn't have any overtime or very strict deadlines, but I heard that's not necessarily the case for all other teams. Morgan Stanly communicates to have a very strong culture of operating by its core values, and as far as I experienced, this isn't just communication. There is a very strong focus on being inclusive and promoting diversity. Junior team members are always welcome by seniors. Managers are approachable.
cons: In our team the system had huge inertia, any change was very slow to go through, and I felt that management was at least partly to blame for it. The true core value is still shareholders' value.

pros: Excellent training program and institutional resource pool for aspiring wealth managers. Competitive revenue goals, but achievable with outsized effort and preparation. Recommend joining a team ASAP, preferably before walking in. Greater optionality for specialization/practice design and more entrepreneurial in nature versus competitors (at the time, at least). Wide range of resources to field opportunities outside of day-to-day business (ex. lending, investment banking division referrals for capital raises).
cons: Sales skills valued over investment sophistication; get established fast or apply to a leading RIA. Revenue targets can be difficult without a strong network and constant activity; work long hours (less con, more advisement). However, favors salespeople and encourages FAAs to outsource services in order to scale client books (i.e. automate and protect client retention at your expense).

pros: Excellent people and culture. Solid support for employees in every aspect.
cons: HR is a total joke, just like everywhere else, they are the epitome of incompetence, backward thinking and resistance to change. Unless it’s about yet another flavor of the day woke bs then they are all over it. Also, MS will work you to the bone if you allow it. Have some boundaries about separating your personal and professional lives, learn to stand your ground and you’ll be fine.

pros: 1. good company culture from the top down. They care about people at least on paper and in principle. 2. good name to be on your CV. 3. Exposure to very interesting products especially in ISG. 4. Onsite gym and canteen 5. Generally collaborative within and across teams
cons: 1. compensation can be uncompetitive compared to peer banks, especially for juniors and internal promotes, which can be unfair when contractors and external hires get paid much more. 2. salary increase is minimal year on year. 3. you can be pigeon-holed covering one area/product type for a long time. 4. job security can be lacking, especially for non-performers. Every year, there are people being let go. 5. Everything is pretty much in-house with complicated system dependencies and as a result, it can be difficult to update/change things.

job_title: Senior Registered Client Service Associate in Southlake, TX
pros: It depends who is on the team that you support. Some colleagues and Advisors are great to work with, others are not. The work is overly easy, if you are looking for a challenge, this is not it.
cons: 1. In experienced Management 2. If you enjoy being managed like a piece of company owned technology, this may be the right fit for you 3. culture can be very demeaning to say the least. A CSA is to put up with being talked down to consistently. I had one advisor that would consistently speak to me in a very demeaning manner. I was hired to support the largest team in the branch and he was later added solo to me in addition. He was the one of the worst people I have worked with. I would tell him what needed to be done opps wise and he would argue and copy my manager. My manager would reply informing I was correct. It was known across the market, the last CSA had the same exact issues. I copied in an opps rep and she witnessed. She informed me "Honestly, with _____, I thought he just had an issue working with women, but as it turns out he has this issue working with everyone." 4. The company has a policy that when an employee leaves, they do not get paid out for vacation. It is a slap in the face 5. Management will lie and make up policies. For example, I was with the firm for over 6 months in 2020. The initial hiring manager guaranteed there would be a 3% raise at the end of the year. The new BSM in Fort Worth stated I was not getting a raise because I walk brought in making so much more than the majority of CSA's in the market. Ummm hello, thats because 1. i am experienced and 2. I a licensed where as the others are not. no wonder why it caused to me being very demotivated. 6. Company is overly bureaucratic. An employee cannot say anything at all without fear of losing their job/manager retaliation 7. BSM in Fort Worth was really a horrible coach to say the very least. We would have monthly calls. She would not lead the call herself regardless and at one point got mad stating "I am trying to get to know you." Please note I was written up for complete BS less than 1 month later. Oh and she had to have her boss on the phone with her because she was overly nervous and sounded like she was about to cry. It's work, not personal, I dont want or need to know my boss on that level. Fast Forward a year, manager skips 2-3 monthly 1:1's consecutively and gave a 5% $3000 raise. in April, during my 1:1, the manager appeared to really be really disengaged and bored during the call. At the end, she goes off real quick on whatever issue she claimed, threw out accusations and hung up without allowing me to respond. Fast forward a month later, I was terminated on May 31 with no write up and left completely rehirable by the firm. She clearly stated that I was fully rehirable and the termination would only impact me in Dallas (Pelase note she was also fully aware that I was to the final stage of the interview process for a role in NYC with the firm). My last official day was June 1 and as she stated solely for insurance purposes only, aka they knew they were doing me wrong. To start the termination, the branch manager of the Southlake Branch, pulled me off a conference call with my team, I asked what was going on, he goes shhh, we walk i ask again, he goes SHHHH (im not an idiot, I knew something was up all day long), he walked me to a closed conference room pauses opens the door, the Fort Worth BSM smiles and says "Are you surprised to see me?" at the end she goes "So, did this really surprise you?" She really proved her lack of experience in handling, because even I know that as a manager you say as little as possible in those instances. IT IS IMPORTANT TO NOTE, after I left, management decided not to fill my role within the branch and cut the position altogether even though they knew the need that the head advisor for my team had especially after his accident the preceding year. This shouldve been a lay-off, not a termination given that the position was cut. But in the end, an analysis would not have left me as the least qualified rep in the branch........ But in the end, its all good, I landed a much better role with significantly higher pay.

pros: excellent place for someone in their 20's to start a financial career, can be stressful , can be overwhelming, can be a little cookie cutter, but overall excellent place to start -exposure to different trading products, systems, processes, teams -similarly motivated and engaged coworkers -hybrid schedule -occasional free food/lunch/happy hour -state of the art offices with amenities -business casual dress code -PTO is amazing 4 weeks off the bat, solid benefits -overtime, you will work overtime if you don't you're doing something wrong

Any type of finance career you will have team and group meetings which feel mundane, yea it sucks but it's part of corporate America this is not a Morgan Stanley exclusive con -big company so other teams take care of different functions and sometimes you will have to hound them to take care of stuff/update information because the clients will be hounding you. This is most def by biggest complaint because everything is on a time crunch so if your client is calling/emailing/messaging/emailing your manager asking for an update on something you can not change is stressful, because you are waiting for a different team to update the information but they of course have their workload as well. Overall it's just a lot of moving pieces , and some people just don't care about their job and deadlines as much but that is at any place of work -the training can be light. Usually you have a few shadow sessions with a senior team member and then start with a light load after about 2-3 weeks of shadowing. overall you need to learn as you go and ask questions and take notes so you are not asking the same questions.

review_title: High on functional domain knowledge, but lagging on tech innovation, HIPPO culture
pros:
Great people-centric work culture. Very professional and structured corporate environment. Mostly merit-driven but career progression may be slow. 
Great place to learn finance, accounting, working with global teams. One will build deep domain expertise if one stays long - will result in competitive advantage in financial services technology. Globalised exposure to markets, financial norms, and processes. 

Decent (not exciting or top tier) compensation compared to IT Services firms.
cons:
MS, about 15-20 years back was a leading technology firm on wall street (though it is a financial services org) - pioneering cutting edge technology infrastructure, tooling and processes. But since then, it has missed the technology evolution and innovation bus. Many of its systems and platforms are legacy over 15 years old, innovation is very slow. Risk taking in technology is discouraged and generally very difficult to bring in new technology stacks or experiment with new technology. 

Senior technology leadership is more focused on funcitonal domain knowledge and people/client/user perception management over technology innovation, risk taking and leap-frogging. There is a strong element of HIPPO (Highest Paid Person's Opinion counts) culture too - if you dont agree with your manager or super manager, it can lead to your career stalling. So it encourages conformance and rarely any disagreements will be taken lightly.

At one time, it used to be in top 10 percentile of compensation for technology based roles, priding itself as the best engineering shop on Wall street. But since the last decade of the software boom and after the 2008 financial crisis, it is not even in the top 25 percentile. Compensation is no longer exciting, growth is slow compared to new age startups and product technology firms such as FAANG. Even now, Cloud computing is a novelty and buzzword at MS and there is no definite roadmap for implementation. Teams in non-US locations are generally disempowered and not part of key ownership or decision making processes. Center of power continues to be NY and unless the users are in your location, you will be treated as second class corporate citizens. 
FOMO, and disempowerment drives Indian technologists to accommodate calls at unreasonable times and being deferential to less competent colleagues abroad. Due to global nature of work expect calls at odd times of days/late evenings to cover or work with colleagues in other timezones.

review_title: Opportunities for People Willing to Put in the Effort
job_title: Chief Operations Officer-COO in Purchase, NY
pros: There are smart and engaging people to work with. A myriad of opportunities for your career path if you work hard/smart. A good income and great benefits.
cons: Too much bureaucracy and too many meetings.

pros: Most people are great and it was a positive environment, never had any issues with my team on a day to day basis.
cons:
-Compensation was way below market averages unless you worked a lot of overtime. While you get a generous amount of PTO, the benefits were average, and commuter benefits were practically non existent as well (e.g. parking or gas stipend). 

-High turnover. As a result of low compensation, people were constantly leaving, causing teams to be short staffed continuously. This happened to my team and many other teams in my department. 

-Long hours. As a result of being short staffed, the hours were terrible. The OT pay was nice (1.5x), but working 50-60 hour weeks to only make the market average was not worth it. 

-Work flexibility was poor. While a lot of companies have moved to a hybrid environment as necessary, it felt forced at MS. My work could be done from home easily. I was personally less productive in office, but still was mandated to come in 3 times a week. In a world where you can easily find fully remote jobs and considering MS's shortcomings in the previously discussed items, this was not really acceptable to me. 

-Technology was extremely outdated. They didn't even give me a laptop when I had to work from home during COVID. You are expected to use your own computer. If that wasn't bad enough, the software we used was all very old, 32 bit, and applications constantly ran out of memory. This worsened productivity and caused more errors/problems. On top of that the technological tools I used were not transferable at all besides Excel; they need to use industry standards. 

-Difficulty in changing roles. I often heard it was possible to switch to a different team if you were interested in something else during my undergrad internship, but once I was hired on full time, it was clear that internal hiring is practically non existent. I never saw anyone successfully change roles, and it was never encouraged. However, when management felt like it they changed my role without me having any say. I liked my initial role and was moved, and was given a new manager twice. Seemed like internal changes only happened at management's discretion.

review_title: Not the same company that it used to be.
pros: Most of the people are nice and sometimes a blessing to work with. Adapted to a hybrid model for now but that is subject to change. Decent health benefits.
cons: Doesn't hold the same core values as a company as they once did. The concept of doing the right thing is often frowned upon and discouraged as senior management tends to withhold the truth from colleagues and employees. The work/home life balance that once existed is gone. If you don't have children, you are expected to work later/earlier to make sure deadlines are met while those with children are encouraged to log off at a reasonable time to have work/home life balance. You truly are just an employee number; they don't care about you beyond that. You are only valued based on your job title. Support roles are considered irrelevant until management needs something. If you encounter a difficult personality and they worked in HR at all during their employment at Morgan Stanley, they are considered protected. You might as well change departments or look for jobs outside of the firm as that person will never be held accountable if they do anything wrong or inappropriate.

pros:
I have been working with Morgan Stanley Bangalore for 6+ months but below 1 year.

Sharing my experience as I joined Morgan Stanley from a Tech giant previously.

1. From a hiring standpoint the salary hike was competitive for the role.

2. Benefits are decent, nothing much to complaint, but don't expect more if you were working for a tech giant before who might have added additional benefits for fitness re-imbursement. I heard it is available but for people at a higher designation level.

3. For the office transportation facility the firm sets the expectation in the beginning that it is a shuttle service during 08:00 AM - 7:PM Login/ logout so no door to door pickup and drop, however if you login a bit late you will have just the door-door drop (Better than not having any thing from my stand point). I feel this should not be a problem unless any one has specific concerns.

4. Usually it is day shift here in which lot of people work. I have not yet heard or seen any one logging in during Night shift (Again I might be wrong as I have not see this.) which is good not to have night shifts.

5. Work culture: This depends on the team you are hired. I work for the technology division in Bangalore location India. The culture from my experience is really good. My manager chases me if he sees me extending my shift so, yes they seem to be concerned with work life balance.

6. Usually the managers for a employee here are employees working from other countries. In some cases you might have your manager located in India its self. Advantage of managers from different location is (again my thought), you do not have that typical Indian culture of manager. People out side the country probably would treat you better.

7. The firm and Management expect employees to be transparent in terms if any blunders done or any mistakes done during the job role so things can be corrected.

8. I have seen they encourage to take leaves as well, which is good. The leaves given are around 21-23 which look similar to other companies.

9. Usually Indian holidays are applicable, but I guess it depends on your team as well. Most Indian holidays are covered but NOT all.

10. The office premises has a cafeteria, decent snacks are available. Food is available currently as offices are open post COVID and the meal is free. But not sure until when this free meal will be applicable how is it going to be.

11. Colleagues are open to help if you are stuck with work related issues. In my experience and team, I have not seen any one being harsh for not knowing some thing.
cons:
1. Hiring process is a bit slow, could be good to see an Improvement.

2. Many employees were shocked to hear during the on-boarding that the firm expects you to close your existing trading accounts and transfer the shares to a new trading account which Morgan Stanley has tie-up with two banks and the conditions are:
A. Your new trading account will be monitored by Morgan Stanley.
B. You can't invest on all stocks and can invest on specific stocks ONLY.

Note - Your shares previously purchased can be still kept/ transferred to the new account or sold so this is available. You can't use them further or invest on stocks which are not allowed.

I don't trade so this did not effect me. But was shocking for people who trade. I guess this is why they pay more to hire due to this hidden condition which is disclosed after joining.

3. Officially from a dress code standpoint as per the HR documents in India, I did not see Jeans mentioned for India region. However I have seen folks wearing jeans including me and nobody has asked me about my dress. So would like to see this culture change with dressing. Based on my discussion with my manager from the other region it is not mandatory to be in formals, seems the India specific thing. (Hoping this should NOT be considered as a factor for joining or not joining a company as other Indian companies also enforce formals ).

The political climate is difficult. It’s not exactly cutthroat or mean-spirited, but everyone wants to take credit for the very few things that move forward or gain traction, so you have competing interests, lack of cohesion, etc.

review_title: Left hand doesn’t know what the right is doing
pros: It’s a job. Better to have one than not. We are allowed to work from home 2x a week. Downgrade from when I started (fully remote) but I am a believer that we should be grateful for what we have, and it’s easy to take things for granted. Sure beats working 5 days in office which would of been the norm pre covid
cons: Terrible onboarding and training experience. Terrible process for making sure employees have correct entitlements to perform their job duties. I can say this is not an isolated issue, as every person I’ve known that has switched roles (including manager level) has experienced issues with not being able to pull up certain accounts or not being able to access relevant applications. It’s not great pay but I accepted because I was desperate after a 2 year work hiatus, maybe I could of negotiated more. I think, fundamentally, the issue is that Morgan Stanley has acquired so many different companies/segments (E*Trade, solium, share works, whatever) without giving much thought on how to successfully integrate all of the new business units/segments/accounts. Not only from client perspective, but for the employees also. Finally, I feel like I might be at some sort of generational threshold between millennial and Gen z….honestly feels as if the younger crowd is doing the bare minimum and really couldn’t care less about client service. I try to help my colleagues out by leaving very detailed notes re: what actions need to be taken in the event the client calls in. More often than not, these notes are completely disregarded and in spite of our service model championing “1 call resolution” (which could of been achieved if my colleagues bothered to read my notes), poor client has to call in multiple times to get a standard request completed. Do they not teach kids to read in college anymore? Oh wait, I don’t even think this role requires a degree, but last I checked, they did teach kids how to read in elementary school

review_title: A year of facing extreme stress but also learning valuable skills
pros: My team members were extremely helpful, kind and would always try to help when their capacity was low. I will always appreciate the kind sending off gift they all gave me! Learnt a lot from my teammates regarding new processes and tips. Flexible for holidays getting approved. Great for getting first hand experience from a graduate role and learning key skills and enhancing knowledge in the financial sector.
cons: Management was utterly awful. For the majority of the year when I was working in the focus bookings team, I felt like a number and I was never given an opportunity to work in different categories despite requesting multiple times. Our team was extremely understaffed and each colleague was assigned to multiple categories which is far too much for one person on days we had absences. Absolutely no organisational structure in the team - people are assigned to completely different categories on the rota for the following week despite having little to no training on these.

job_title: Client Service Associate in Tampa, FL
pros: The benefits are pretty good and having the company name on your resume opens doors at other firms.
cons: High expectations with inadequate training. In this complex branch they love to micro manage. If they put that same effort into mentoring their employees as they put into micro managing then the division would be much more successful. Micro management is done through digital communication, which is highly impersonal. Time is monitored by the second, including bathroom breaks. They are generous with vacation allowances; however, the calendar to request off seems to have more unavailable black out days than days available. Typical workday is sitting on the phone with frustrated clients most of the day. Pay is inadequate. They recently had a "stay conversation" with employees, which goes to show how poor retention is. They continue to squeeze employees in this role more and more and they will continue to leave. The points we made in the stay conversation have appeared to have fallen on deaf ears... If they're not going to listen I don't know why they would even bother to ask.

job_title: Virtual Financial Advisor in London, England
pros:
You get your licensing (series 7,63,66). You get a lot of experience building financial plans and making portfolio recommendations. Do not have to build your own book. Promotion is based on performance not on time in job.
Salary is competitive. You start as a "Foundations" Advisor, pay is around $65k with bonus around $10k. Then move to Level 1 with pay at $70k and bonus at $15k. Level 2 is $80k with $25k bonus potential. Bonus is based on team performance, so highest performer receives 100% of bonus amount, second highest 95%, etc. Good pay but bonus structure could be improved.
cons: It's a call center environment at the end of the day. You will deal with a lot of service related issues. Training is OK not great.

review_title: Overall excellent, permanent WFH would have been ideal
job_title: Team Financial Advisor in Gilbert, AZ
pros: Great pay for the Tampa Metro Area. Around or over 20 days of PTO. Bank holidays + easier days on market holidays. Weekends off. Great culture surrounding mental health, especially for the finance industry (maybe advisory services are very different from Investment Banking and Hedge Funds). There is a PTO calendar (that lets you know which days are available and which are not) and plenty of workers, so no one is ever left with too much work due to folks taking vacations, at least for this position. Also the calendar is very systematic and in-line with policies, so there's less room to be denied vacation due to management. They pay for your Series 7 and 66 training materials and 4 hours per workday to study for those exams during your first 3 months.
cons: Busy. Lunch is only 30 minutes, not enough time to do much else but eat (no time for a productivity nap or other tasks). Certainly not enough time to grab and eat food from a restaurant. Perhaps too great of a focus on growth/sales, instead of client satisfaction and retention/growth through word-of-mouth and positive experiences. The impression given is that you're there to advise clients, but actually there's an incentive to get their money invested (via metrics and bonuses), even if you have reason to believe cash will perform better and be less risky than most investments, after fees, in the short-term (1-2 years). I suppose you could focus on getting clients to sell out of their investments/convert to cash, but that is rarely presented as an option and the system will let others within the company know that that client is all cash/not having their money working for them and that they should get invested. The Return-To-Office Hawk CEO is a bit of a con. But otherwise a great CEO.

review_title: Good company but don't trust management
job_title: Financial Advisor Associate Program in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Morgan Stanley has some of the best resources for advisors of any company. (i.e. research, technology, etc.)
cons:
Be careful of anyone who isn't an advisor (Managers, employees, trainers, compliance, service professionals, etc.).

Most advisors are good people and will either be willing help or indicate they don't have time or aren't interested. Some advisors may seemingly take advantage of junior advisors and try to work with their clients (or prospective clients) however this type of relationship can still benefit both parties since you are able to split the business with them and learn to close new business.

On the other hand, management will lie and mislead people for their own benefit. Other employees (i.e. service professionals, compliance, trainers, etc.) cannot be trusted either because of the culture that exists at the company. Someone will gladly stab you in the back to save their skin or simply for their own benefit. 

My advice: remember that "There are no friends on Wall Street".

job_title: Senior Director in New York, NY
pros: Benefits are good and they offer unique networking opportunities like virtual museum tours, zoom fitness classes, and mental health time off. They do offer great work/life balance also.
cons: This is truly then most toxic culture I have ever experienced. If you are talented your manager and peers will take credit for your work and smother your potential then make you do all their work for them. They are status-quo people and feel if you don't like it just take mobility. Mobility is the dumbest thing I've ever seen since they have no onboarding program so when someone does take mobility they are set up for failure and have a much longer time adapting and learning the role that they are unqualified to take to begin with. My entire department came through from mobility and had no clue to how do their jobs. I felt like I was in the 13th grade working with these people. My management was the most incompetent group of people I've ever worked with and our ED couldn't even make their own PowerPoint slides themselves let alone know how to use a software system. The pay is below average and they want to overwork you if you're talented. They have no development which is why their leadership is trash. They promote based on tenure and not talent so expect to train your boss for years and get nowhere. I'm unsure how Morgan Stanley is successful at all, honestly. The incompetence, lack of diversity, and politics, makes this place seem like 1985. I'm sure there are some good departments but few and far between . The people are not kind or welcoming and it's a shark culture when there is no reason for it. No one will help you either if you complain and ask for help. It's a no win situation working here. If you work here, you're stuck with people treating you like trash until you leave. Not worth your mental health.

review_title: Good In Compensation Pretty Bad in Work Life Balance & Respect At Work.
pros:
I have been associated with the fir for past 7+ years and taking the opportunity to share some information for the aspiring candidates.

Good Pay Structure 
1). Unlimited Sick Leaves (You need to Show Medical Certificate for More than 2 Days)
2). 4 Weeks Parental Care Leave (If Parents are Hospitalised)
3). 5 Days Bereavement Leave (In Case of Death of 1st family Member)
4). 21 Paid Leaves (Cannot be Carried Forward or Paid Out)
cons:
Below are some cons.

1). Continuously changing leadership (I have worked with 9 managers in past 7 years but still in the same project).

2). No clarity on project and task in hand. In some cases after completing 50% of project you will be asked to change the approach/ framework just because you have hit a road block.

3). Poor work life balance. As the requirement and ask keeps on changing you would be required to work late nights and weekend to achieve the targets. 

4). Poor culture, no respect at work. They follow onshore offshore delivery model and the Indian managers sitting in US treat people very badly if you are unable to achieve the targets. They will start working at 11:00 AM EST and expect you to join mid night calls.

5). Very high attrition rates most of the employees tend to leave the organisation in 1-2 years looking at pressure. 

6). Use your personal computer for working from home even during COVID times.

7). Recent mergers and acquisition has led in too many resignation in the in leadership team.

pros: Fine if you’re a male employee

review_title: My experience working for Morgan Stanley at Work (aka ShareWorks)
pros: They provide extra days off over and above vacation time (i.e. your birthday off, three extra days in the summer)
cons:
There is a very large emphasis and pressure on becoming a leader in your team. You will be constantly pushed into participating in leadership extracurricular activities even if this does not suit your personality. All careers paths in the company lead to a role which requires leadership responsibilities even if you are a developer. The company seems to be trying to mold all employees into the same type of person (extraverted, outgoing, and leadership material).

They are forcing employees to come into the office 3 days a week. They cannot provide a good justification for this decision and have actually stated that they have seen that employees work very effectively and more efficiently from home. From my personal observations a large portion of the employees at Morgan Stanley at Work are unhappy with the orders to come into the office. Management has been struggling to get people to follow the orders (they are not seeing enough people come in each week). This makes me as an employee feel like Morgan Stanley does not care about what the majority of it's employees want.

There is no concept of a Software Development Lead who runs the Agile ceremonies. Instead there are Software Development Managers. All Software Developers have to run the Agile ceremonies themselves.

Note: This is only a con if you are not a fan of public speaking. Compared to other companies I have worked for and what I have heard from other Software Developers about their companies Morgan Stanley at Work requires a lot of presentations and demos from it's employees.

review_title: Morgan Stanley Has Work To Do!
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Alpharetta, GA
pros: Would have been the ability to work from home, until they switched to hybrid.
cons: Had to use our personal cellphone and computer for work, PROCESSES ARE OUT OF DATE. They need a more efficient way to resolve clients issues... You have to go through 10 different channels to find the solution to one problem. There is no help desk, all questions are asked and answered through skype.. There can be up to 100 people in the chat at once, questions get overlooked, and take too long to be answered. Meanwhile, you have to keep checking in with the client, which makes them frustrated, and makes you look like you dont know what you are doing. Reaching out to the branches are a JOKE, most of them don't answer! Lastly, the Financial advisors are rude to the reps... We were expected to remain professional, but the advisors talk to you like you are subpar, as if you dont work for the same company! Morgan Stanley should hold them to a higher standard of professionalism. When expressed to team manager, they act as though you should be understanding because of their workload, as if it wasn't a very stressful job for ALL OF US! The wage needs to be increased for all that you are required to do!

pros:
Your salary is paid on time. 

There are clear policies and procedures for almost everything. There is little room for uncertainties in how to do business. 

Your role is clearly defined in the contract, and mostly agrees with your job description. 

Free coffee is available at the break-out areas.
cons:
Salary should be negotiated well during interview. Make sure you know what you are worth. After you start, you barely get an increase afterward. Any increases you will receive will definitely be below the changes in cost of living. 

The organization is very bureaucratic and hierarchical. The company culture is such that people who have higher titles than you make sure you understand that you are speaking to a senior person when you interact with them. 

You are supposed to do exactly what you are told to do. You do not really have the opportunity to make suggestions in what you see as failing, or put your ideas forward. You are not going to be listened to. You are not given chance to make impact. 

Incompetent managers, especially at the mid-level. Definitely not experts in their areas. I have the impression that it is their sheer success in company politics that keep them afloat, not their record of achievements, knowledge or wisdom. 

(Unsurprisingly) high turnover rates. The management does nothing to keep people motivated, satisfied and recognized.
